history.content:
UC Berkeley ATDP is looking for an instructor for Algorithms & Data Structures. This will be a summer class for high school students, and it will be taught online class taught online via Zoom
Applying. Please apply by emailing your resume to Carrie Brown, ATDP Assistant Director, at CarrieBrown@berkeley.edu


About ATDP. The Academic Talent Development Program (ATDP) is UC Berkeley’s summer program for high-achieving students from kindergarten to completing grade eleven. For forty years, ATDP has been offering challenging summer classes in a wide variety of disciplines. ATDP unites teachers who love to teach with students who love to learn. Please visit ATDP’s website at https://atdp.berkeley.edu/ to learn more about the program.


ATDP has lesson plans from a past class, and they can be used as a basis for the class and can be modified and expanded. The class will have about twenty-two students. Instructors will be paid through UC Berkeley’s payroll department.


Algorithms and Data Structures
Program dates: June 21 to July 30, 2021
Class schedule: Monday & Wednesday, 8:30 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. (12 class meetings)
Daily schedule: 8:30 a.m. to Noon
Location: Online via Zoom
Pay: $2600 (1 section)


Course Description: This advanced programming course will introduce students to algorithms and their relationship to data structures, touching on several of the concepts covered in a second-year collegiate computer science curriculum. Students should already be familiar with control structures like conditionals, loops, and functions. We will develop a sense for designing algorithms and analyzing how fast they will run. We will start with one-dimensional structures and sorting algorithms, then move to more involved data structures like trees and graphs and their associated problems, such as shortest-path-finding and traversal. By focusing on creating fully-featured projects, we will combine our code with graphical user interfaces to create more powerful, efficient, and useful programs.


Online class structure: Students will spend 2-3 hours per class in interactive lecture and hands-on assignments over Zoom. Students will have substantial breaks throughout.
Who should take the class: Advanced students who wish to extend their programming knowledge into second-year college-level computer science topics


Prerequisite: Completion of Programming in Java or AP Computer Science, or a passing score on a placement test
